section.title: Reflexive pronouns
section.sectiontitle: We use reflexive pronouns to talk about actions where the subject and object are the same person. The reflexive pronoun is essential to the grammar of the sentence and would not make sense without it.
section.text1a: I cut myself while I was cooking. (NOT: I cut while I was cooking.)
section.text2a: She was by herself when the accident happened. (NOT: She was by when the accident happened.)
section.sectiontitle2: The singular reflexive pronouns are: myself / yourself / himself / herself / itself. Plural reflexive pronouns are: ourselves / yourselves / themselves.

section.title: Reflexive pronouns
section.sectiontitle: We can also use reflexive pronouns for emphasis, when we mean 'that person or thing, and nobody or nothing else'. In this case, the reflexive pronoun is not essential to the grammar of the sentence, but is added for emphasis.
section.text1: I didn't manage to speak to the boss, only his secretary.
section.text1a: I didn't manage to speak to the boss himself, only his secretary.
